The above is the first teaching of the Three Refuges, the beginning of entering. From here below is the second teaching
of the middle way, the end of entering.
In this, first there is a doctrinal explanation, and below just as from milk there is an explanatory analogy.
There are four in the doctrine:

First, permission to teach and enter; second, below if I abide, the correct teaching of entering; third, below I and non-self nature are non-dual, concluding and exhorting to uphold; fourth, below I previously at, citing explanations to prove.

The first says I will now further explain to you entering the TathÄgata's storehouse, permitting the teaching of entry. Facing the previous, it says further, and the further explanation is later, thus it says will. Detailed explanation is called good, revealing the truth and causing realization is called explaining entering the storehouse.
In the second teaching, the text is divided into four parts:
First, facing the biased views of ordinary beings on annihilation and permanence, clarifying the two aspects of phenomena;
Second, from ordinary beings have no doubts about this and below, it refutes the two views of existence and non-existence held by ordinary beings, clarifying that the principle is non-dual;
Third, from if it is said that suffering and below, it refutes the biased views of the two vehicles, clarifying that the characteristics are truly dual;
Fourth, from if it is said that ignorance conditions formations and below, it refutes the two different views held by the two vehicles, clarifying that there is truly no duality.
First and third, how are the two different?
The first clarifies the two of the characteristics of birth and death and nirvana, while the third clarifies the two of the true nature of the characteristics of the conditioned arising of dharmas.
Second and fourth, how are the non-dualities different?

In the second section, it clarifies the non-duality of existence and non-existence in the nature of dharmas, while in the fourth section it clarifies the non-duality of before and after in its true nature, like the non-duality of the taste of milk and curd in the cow, and also reveals the true non-duality of the characteristics of all dharmas.

In the first section, it first clarifies the biased views of permanence and annihilation of ordinary beings, and below for this reason it refutes emotional views and clarifies the two aspects of phenomena.
In clarifying the views of ordinary beings, there are five pairs:
The first pair clarifies the faults, the middle three correctly discern the two aspects of annihilation and permanence, and the last pair clarifies the basis for the arising of views.

In the first pair, if the self abides raises the view of permanence. Those with the view of permanence say that there is a divine self abiding within the five aggregates, called the abiding of the self, which is a permanent dharma.
Not apart from suffering clarifies the fault based on that. Non-Buddhists proclaim that the divine self is permanent, so following their intention it is said to be a permanent dharma.
The five aggregates are suffering. The self abiding within the aggregates is called not apart from suffering.

If there is no self raises the view of annihilation. Those with the view of annihilation say that there is no arising or ceasing, and the nominally existent self, up to the true self of nirvana, is also non-existent, generally called no self.
Practice is not beneficial is used to show the fault, because without self there is nothing to nourish, therefore there is no benefit.

Among the three pairs, the first pair distinguishes annihilation and permanence based on the views of self and no-self, the second pair is based on the views of permanence and impermanence, and the third pair is based on the views of suffering and happiness.
In the first pair, If it is said that all dharmas are without self refers to the previous no-self. Samsara and nirvana are both without self, therefore it says all are without.
This is the view of annihilation concludes annihilation as different from permanence.
If it is said that the self abides refers to the previous view of self, this is the view of permanence concludes permanence as different from annihilation.

In the second pair, If it is said that all conditioned things are impermanent brings up the view of impermanence. This says that the dharmas of samsara and nirvana are both annihilated, therefore it is called impermanent, not the impermanence of transformation before and after.
This is the view of annihilation concludes annihilation as different from permanence.
If one says that all conditioned things are permanent presents the view of permanence, meaning that it is said that the five aggregates of conditioned things are all permanent.
This is also the view of permanence concludes that permanence is different from annihilation.

In the third pair, if one says that all is suffering presents the view of suffering, which means that it is said that there is no real happiness in the world at all, and even the true happiness of nirvana does not exist, and is generally called the view of suffering.
This is the view of annihilation concludes that annihilation is different from permanence.
If one says that all is happiness presents the view of happiness, which means that it is said that there is definitely true happiness in samsara, and is called the view of happiness.
This is also the view of permanence concludes that permanence is different from annihilation.
Below, it clarifies the reasons for the arising of the two views, which is that permanence gives rise to annihilation and annihilation gives rise to permanence.
In this, first is the teaching, next is the analogy, and finally is the combination.
In the teaching, cultivating permanence falls into the view of annihilation means that because one seeks permanence and does not attain it, one gives rise to the view of annihilation;
Cultivating all cessation - the one who previously held the view of permanence seeks cessation but does not attain it, thus giving rise to the view of permanence.
In the analogy, moving the previous cause to the later foot means that the two views of cessation and permanence alternate as previous and later.
The combined text can be understood.

The above is the first to clarify the biased views of ordinary people. Below is the second, which refutes biased views and clarifies the two aspects of phenomena. First, it distinguishes, and then concludes.
In the distinction, there are three pairs:
First, using suffering and joy as opposites to distinguish the two aspects of phenomena, second, using self and non-self as opposites, and third, using permanence and impermanence as opposites.
Among them, impermanence, suffering, and non-self are the dharmas of birth and death, while permanence, joy, and self are the dharmas of nirvana.

Among the dharmas of birth and death, suffering is called unwholesomeness which is the cause of birth and death, non-self and afflictions are the conditions of birth and death, and impermanent wealth is the fruit of birth and death. In reality, they are equally pervasive, but they are spoken of in terms of concealment and manifestation.

In the Dharma of nirvana, happiness is called good refers to the holy path, self is called the secret treasury refers to nirvana, and permanence is called the correct liberation of the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha refers to bodhi. The principle is also equally applicable, just hidden and revealed.
In the first pair, for this reason means that because ordinary people one-sidedly grasp both [views of] annihilation and permanence, the principle must be learned in both [ways].

Cultivating other dharmas that are suffering are all called unwholesome, cultivating other dharmas that are happiness are called good means that learning contemplation is called cultivation. Suffering is saá¹ƒsÄra, and happiness is nirvana. They are distinguished by contrasting them. Therefore, it is said other.

Unwholesome is the cause of suffering. The cause is named after the effect, so it is called suffering. It can also be said that the effect of suffering is named after the cause, so it is called unwholesome;
Good is the cause of happiness. The cause is named after the effect, so it is called happiness. It can also be said that the effect of happiness is named after the cause, so it is called good.
In the second pair, cultivating the non-self of dharmas refers to the dharmas of birth and death. Birth and death are unreal and not independent, so they are called non-self.

Afflictions are the conditions for birth and death. Because of the afflictions, what is received is unreal and not independent. The name is established based on the effect, so it is called non-self. Alternatively, non-self can be named based on the root and called afflictions.
Moreover, this nature of afflictions is unreal and not an independent dharma, so it is called non-self. Therefore, non-self is precisely the afflictions.
Cultivating the other permanence refers to the dharma of nirvÄá¹‡a. This is precisely the self. Using permanence to illustrate it.

This is because when speaking of self, people happily grasp it as having feeling. The dharma is distinguished by permanence and called the secret treasury. It is precisely nirvÄá¹‡a. NirvÄá¹‡a is the true self. Subtle and hidden, it is called secret. Endowed with virtues, it is called a treasury.
That is to say, nirvÄá¹‡a refutes its essence and characteristics. Wonderfully transcending all existence, it is called without a den.

Cultivating the impermanent refers to the dharmas of birth and death, and the wealth refers to the fruits of birth and death, which are called wealth. Cultivating the permanent refers to the dharma of nirvana. The Buddha Dharma and so forth refute its essence and characteristics. This Buddha Dharma is simply bodhi.

Next, it concludes, One should know that such Buddha Dharma is the middle way. It correctly concludes based on its characteristics, and explains the meaning of the middle by clarifying the true that is apart from the two.
It is apart from the two extremes of annihilation and permanence of ordinary beings, and is therefore called the middle way, not a middle that is apart from the two.
Below is the second, which is a pair that dispels the two views of existence and nonexistence of ordinary beings, clarifying that principle is not dual.
Within this there are two:
The first clarifies that the two views of ordinary beings are contrary to the middle, and the second, below Just as the four elements, clarifies that the Buddha's teachings are not dual.

Within the first, there are two phrases. The first, Ordinary beings have no doubts within it, clarifies that ordinary beings do not recognize the middle way. Ordinary beings have no mind that grasps at the middle way that is apart from the two, and therefore do not give rise to doubts;
If they do not even give rise to doubt, how could they possibly understand and know?

Second, below the weak and sick, it clarifies how ordinary beings establish the two characteristics. First, it sets up a metaphor. The sick person is a metaphor for the ordinary, whose understanding is inferior and called weak, and whose mind is afflicted by delusion and called sick. Consuming and accepting deviant teachings is called having taken ghee. Taking attachment to existence is called light and easy. The nature of ghee is soft and weak, and when a sick person takes it, their body lacks strength. Swaying with things is called light and easy.
Deviant teachings are like this. Ordinary beings listen and accept them, taking attachment to existence, and are unable to abide correctly, like being light and easy.
Existence and non-existence are not fixed combines this to illustrate the teaching.
Below it clarifies how the Tathagata refutes and dispels the two attachments of ordinary beings, and teaches them the non-dual.
Within this there are four parts:ğŸ”½First, it corresponds to the later section on the sickness of existence and non-existence, and allows the teaching to eliminate and sever them;
Second, below opening and revealing, it corresponds to the earlier section on having no doubts in the middle, and allows the teaching to lead them to enter;
Third, If you say it exists, wisdom should not... below, it corresponds to the first point above, and correctly teaches the elimination of [wrong views].
Fourth, If you say it exists, you should not be silent... below, it corresponds to the second point above, and correctly teaches the arising and entering [of right views].
In the first section, there is first a simile, and then a combination [of the simile and the teaching].
In the simile, The nature of the four great elements is different, and they each oppose each other illustrates the opposition between the two views of existence and non-existence above.
The good doctor knows well, and follows their biased manifestations to treat them illustrates that the Tathagata knows the biased strength of faults and eliminates them.
In the combination, the first sentence about the difference between the four great elements is not combined in brief, but only combines the later sentence about the good doctor treating them.

The Tathagata is also like this, regarding birth he is like a doctor combines the good doctor above, knowing the differences in the essence and characteristics of all afflictions combines the knowing well above, and eliminates them combines the biased manifestations to treat them above.
The characteristics of elimination are as explained in the following text.
In the second part, it reveals the secret treasury.
The pure buddha-nature is always unchanging means that in contrast to ordinary beings who have no doubts about it, it is allowed to be revealed and explained, causing them to enter into it.
The characteristics of revealing are as explained later.
Below this is the third part, which correctly shows what was mentioned earlier as the characteristics of elimination and severance.
If it is said to exist, wisdom should not be defiled teaches the abandonment of the view of existence.
If one hears that the Dharma exists, a wise person should not be attached to it and grasp it as definitely existing.
If it is said to be nonexistent, it is a lie teaches the abandonment of the view of nonexistence.
If it is said that all buddhas are nonexistent, it contradicts the principles of the Dharma and is therefore a lie.

Below this is the fourth part, which correctly shows what was mentioned earlier as revealing the meaning of the secret treasury of buddha-nature, clarifying that buddha-nature is neither existent nor nonexistent.

If it is said to exist, one should not remain silent clarifies that nature is not nonexistent, because if it is not nonexistent, one should explain to others that the true nature exists and should not remain silent.
How can it be said to exist?
There are two kinds of distinctions:
The first is the nature of the Dharma Buddha, which from the very beginning surpasses the innumerable dharmas of all Buddhas, like gold in an ore;

The second is the nature of the retribution Buddha, which from the very beginning has within the mind the meaning of being able to give rise to all virtues and principles, like gold in an ore having the meaning of being able to create adornments.
One should also not engage in frivolous arguments and disputes shows that the nature does not exist.
How is it said not to exist?
There are also two kinds of distinctions:
The first is the nature of the Dharma Buddha, which is apart from all characteristics and apart from all natures, and is therefore called non-existent.
How is it apart from characteristics?

Like pure ghee, although its substance is existent, it is without characteristics such as blue, yellow, red, white, etc.; it is also like the mind and consciousness of all sentient beings, whose substance is existent but without characteristics such as large, small, long, short, etc.
Buddha-nature is like this, its substance is truly existent but without a single characteristic.
How is it apart from natures?

The TathÄgata-garbha contains all the Buddha-dharmas beyond the sands of the Ganges, not apart from, not detached from, not different, these Buddha-dharmas having the same essence, mutually integrating, not a single dharma separately guarding its own nature, therefore it is said to be apart from nature.
Second, the nature of the reward Buddha originally only has the meaning of being able to arise but not yet a substance, like a tree seed but without the substance of a tree.
Since the nature is like this, grasping at a definite non-existence within it is contrary to principle, therefore it is encouraged to abandon it.
In the text, it first says one should also not engage in frivolous arguments, directly encouraging the abandonment of existence. Abandoning existence is the same as before, therefore it says also.
Previously encouraging the abandonment of non-existence, again encouraging the abandonment of existence, therefore it says also.
If one grasps at a definite existence, saying it should not accord with the Dharma, then it is called frivolous argument.
Grasping at existence is contrary to emptiness, therefore it is encouraged to abandon it.
Because of this fault, it is encouraged not to engage in it.

But seek understanding means to take the correct meaning, abandon emotions, and focus solely on principle. Therefore it is said to but seek. What is sought in accordance with principle is precisely the true nature of all dharmas.

Ordinary beings and below cite faults to encourage abandonment. The text says disputation and argumentation, not understanding which clearly shows that those who do not understand are capable of understanding.
Question:
Now this discussion of neither existence nor non-existence, what is the difference from the third section above that refutes existence and refutes non-existence? Why come again?
The explanation says:

Moreover, the previous [discussion] refuted definite existence and non-existence within the causes and conditions of worldly truth, while this [discussion] correctly reveals the meaning of the tathÄgatagarbha nature as neither existence nor non-existence, which is different from the previous [discussion], and therefore is further debated.

Below is the third [part], which, in response to the biased views of the two vehicles, clarifies the three realities. Since the two vehicles grasp characteristics and are confused about reality, the Buddha teaches the reality of characteristics to them.
The text is divided into five parts:
The first three reveal the truth in terms of defiled characteristics, while the latter two reveal the truth in terms of pure characteristics.
Within these five sections, there should be three parts in each:

First, citing the Buddha's past teachings; second, clarifying how foolish people cling to characteristics and are confused about the truth; third, clarifying how wise people understand characteristics and know the truth.
However, in the text now, there is either concealment or manifestation, and some have all three while others do not.
Within the first section, there are only two parts, and the third is omitted.
If it is said to be suffering is the first sentence, citing the Buddha's past words. The Buddha said in the past in the teachings for the Lesser Vehicle that the body is all suffering.

Foolish people then think that the body is impermanent and all suffering and so forth is the second sentence. Correctly grasping it as suffering, this clarifies the grasping of characteristics.
And they are unable to know that the body has the nature of bliss shows their confusion about the truth.
One should raise the wise ones, reversing the previous, which can be known, therefore it is omitted.

Raising the Buddha's words from the past.

This is called the Å›rÄvakas taking the ordinary as the truth, seeking words and grasping characteristics, therefore reckoning all as impermanent, like the analogy of a clay vessel.
This text is slightly abbreviated, according to the previous it should say:
And they are unable to know that the body has the nature of permanence, not knowing the nature of permanence is precisely confusion about the truth.
The wise ones and below is the third phrase. Should distinguish generally encourages distinguishing, should not and below specifically teaches distinguishing.
One should not say that everything is impermanent encourages the abandonment of grasping at characteristics. Why is it so? teaches the understanding of reality.
Why is it so? raises the previous point to give rise to the next. Why should one not say that everything is impermanent?
My body itself has the seeds of Buddha-nature correctly teaches with reality.
In the third section, If it is said that there is no self is the first sentence, bringing up the Buddha's words from the past.
Ordinary beings should think that everything is without self is the second sentence, showing how the two vehicles grasp at characteristics and are confused about reality.
However, in this text it only clarifies grasping at characteristics and is brief on being confused about reality.

The wise ones... and below is the third sentence, clarifying how the wise ones understand characteristics and know reality. Should discern that the designation of no self... encourages the understanding of characteristics, encouraging the understanding that no self is confined to the realm of provisional names and not real dharmas.

Having known thus, one should not give rise to doubt encourages them to know the truth. Knowing that the absence of self is confined to provisional names and unreal dharmas, one should not doubt and say there is no self within the true dharmas.

In the fourth section, If one says the secret treasury of the TathÄgata is empty and tranquil is the first sentence, bringing up the Buddha's words from the past. This refers to the nirvÄá¹‡a as the secret treasury.
In the past, the Buddha proclaimed the nirvÄá¹‡a in the teachings for the HÄ«nayÄna as being completely extinguished and non-existent, thus it is called empty and tranquil.

Ordinary beings, upon hearing this, give rise to the view of annihilation is the second sentence, revealing how those of the two vehicles cling to characteristics and are confused about the truth. They say that after the parinirvÄá¹‡a of the TathÄgata, it is completely annihilated and non-existent. It encourages understanding the truth, but briefly lacks the characteristics of wisdom.

One should distinguish that the TathÄgata's transformation and cessation is truly permanent and unchanging.

In the fifth section, If it is said that liberation is like an illusion, is the first sentence, citing the Buddha's words from the past. This says that bodhi is liberation. Thus, in the past in the teachings of breaking down characteristics, it was said that the Buddha's liberation is illusory and unreal, like an illusion. Therefore, the MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ SÅ«tra says, If there is a single dharma that surpasses nirvÄá¹‡a, I would also say it is like an illusion, like a magical creation, let alone nirvÄá¹‡a.

The foolish person and below is the second sentence, showing that the ignorant person grasps at characteristics and is confused about the truth, thinking that the true liberation attained by the Buddha is like an illusion and will eventually return to extinction.
This clarifies the attachment to characteristics, briefly without confusion about the truth.

Those with wisdom is the third sentence, showing that the wise ones understand the characteristics and know the truth. Should distinguish that although the Lion among Humans has coming and going, clarifies their understanding of the characteristics. The Buddha is called the Lion among Humans. Emanation is called coming, and responding to extinction is called going.
Abiding eternally without change clarifies their understanding of the truth.
Below this, the fourth is the counteraction of the two vehicles' discriminating two views, clarifying that in reality there are not two.

It is because those of the two vehicles have not yet realized the truth of dharmas, and see the transformation of flowing dharmas as definitely separate, so it is necessary to refute this and clarify that there are not two. It also refutes the two vehicles' views of characteristics and truth as two, clarifying that they are not two. Because when those of the two vehicles hear of impermanence, suffering, and no-self, there is permanence and so forth, they then consider that those natures are of a separate substance from the characteristics of suffering, no-self, and so forth, and are the same aggregate. Therefore, it is necessary to refute this and clarify that there are not two.
In the text, there are six pairs:

The first three pairs refute the separate views of the two vehicles and clarify non-duality, while the last three pairs refute the two vehicles' views of the reality of duality and clarify non-duality.
How is there non-duality in the first three pairs?
Like wheat, cause and effect are different before and after, but the nature of wheat is not dual;
Up to all milk, yogurt, etc. are different, but the taste of cows is not dual.
The phenomena are like this, clarifying that although ignorance, etc. are different, the true nature is not dual. The one true mind-ground transforms with conditions and becomes all phenomena.
Therefore, the text below says, Together with the bonds, it is called ignorance; together with good dharmas, it is called illumination.
How is there non-duality in the last three pairs?
Like a person in the dark night seeing a rope as a snake, the same substance is divided into meanings, and the substance nature is not dual;
It is also like a person who mistakes south for north, and this south and north are not dual in substance.
All dharmas are like this. Deluded about the tathÄgatagarbha, it becomes saá¹ƒsÄra. The essence of saá¹ƒsÄra is the tathÄgatagarbha. Therefore, it is said there is no duality.
In the first of the three pairs, the first pair is about karma and its results. It speaks of two, and based on these two it clarifies non-duality.
The second pair is about karma and its effects.
The third pair is about good and evil.
The characteristics of dharmas are immeasurable, but for now these three are mentioned, and the rest can be understood by analogy.
In the first pair, If it is said that ignorance is the condition for the various activities, it cites the Buddha's words from the past. Ignorance is afflictions, and the various activities are karma.

Ordinary beings who hear and below clarify how foolish people definitely grasp them as two. This still refers to the two vehicles as ordinary beings, because they have not yet realized and united with the reality of non-duality.
The deluded mind grasps characteristics and is called discrimination. It means that they definitely consider ignorance and activity to be separate, and is called giving rise to the notion of two.

Enlightenment and ignorance are two names. Enlightenment is still the same as karmic activity. Within karmic activity, enlightenment is supreme. Facing ignorance, the two aspects are manifested. Therefore, it is mentioned one-sidedly.

The wise ones and below, relying on the wise ones, clarify that the nature is non-dual. The one true consciousness-only essence follows conditions and transforms into enlightenment and ignorance. Therefore, the nature is non-dual.
It is like the nature of one water following conditions to be clear or turbid. The nature of water is non-dual.
Non-duality is reality summarizes by tying it together.

The text of the contrast between karmic activity and consciousness is evident and can be understood.ğŸ”½In the third contrast, If it is said... and so on, citing the Buddha's words from the past. Ten wholesome and ten unwholesome brings up the essence of karmic activity. Can be done and cannot be done distinguishes karmic activity based on people. The ten wholesome can be done, and the ten unwholesome cannot be done.

Good paths and evil paths contrasts karmic activity based on effects. The ten wholesome universally lead people to the human and heavenly realms, which is called the good paths. The ten unwholesome universally lead people to the three evil destinies, which is called the evil paths.
White dharmas and black dharmas distinguish karma according to characteristics. Good karma is fresh and pure, so it is called white. Evil karma is coarse and defiled, so it is called black.
The two kinds of wisdom are the same as explained above.

The next three pairs discuss the non-duality of the two aspects and reality within the third section above. The text above has five sentences, but for now it clarifies non-duality based on the first three sentences. The rest can be understood by analogy.
If it is said that all suffering should be cultivated refers to the first sentence above. The ordinary person considers them two.

If you say it is impermanent refers to the second point above.

The TathÄgata's secret treasury is also impermanent is like the previous text, where ordinary beings all consider the body to be impermanent, and the Å›rÄvakas, upon hearing the teaching of impermanence in the past teachings, consider that saá¹ƒsÄra and even the secret treasury are all impermanent, so it is mentioned here.

Although they did not hear it, they say that everything is impermanent.
The statement is indiscriminate, and the secret treasury is also included in everything, so it can be said that the TathÄgata's secret treasury is also impermanent.

The two consider it to be two is because those two vehicles considered everything to be impermanent in the past, so the Buddha previously taught them about the nature of impermanence. They, upon hearing this, think that the self is completely separate from no-self, thus saying think of two.
Wisdom understands as non-dual - the meaning is as explained above.
The above four sections together form the second main teaching on entering. From here below is the third, concluding with an exhortation to uphold.
There are four phrases:

The first is a summary praise of the previous meaning, the second is a summary praise of the previous teaching below I now, the third is an exhortation to uphold the previous meaning below I and non-self, and the fourth is an exhortation to uphold the previous teaching below You should also.

In the previous sentence, I and the nature of non-self are not two restates the previous meaning. There are many previous meanings, but it is restated based on the latter. The meaning of the TathÄgata's secret treasury is like this is used to conclude it. It cannot be and below is praise.

In the second sentence, I now have explained all in this sÅ«tra that accomplishes all merits - above it clarifies the principle that can enable sentient beings to rely on it to accomplish merit, therefore it is called a sÅ«tra that accomplishes all merits. This is just a phrase of praise.

The text is divided into four parts:
